comments.commentBody: It is like this they have all the time in the world they can wait Americans out for decades while America goes bankrupt over there like the Soviets did and in the end those folks will be saying we beat another foolish super power that thought they can beat us over here.
Big difference between Vietnam and Afghanistan? No protests.  As long as there are no protests this war will go on forever. Remember Kent State.

This is so sad. The longer Afghanistan drags on, the more I think about Viet Nam. Remember peace with honor? After countless lives were lost while we implemented it, we ended up leaving without peace and without honor. Viet Nam was lost not because of strategic errors, but policy errors. That war could never be won. We sacrificed over 58,000 American lives before we came to that realization.

Afghanistan is similar. We are analyzing our strategy but no strategy will work. The policy we are attempting to implement cannot be implemented. So the conflict drags on. Lives continue to be lost and Americans are being sent home in body bags once again.

The Taliban have no timetable. They have no schedule. They can continue indefinitely. They are not an external invading force that can be driven out. They are indigenous. The constantly regenerate.

After all these years of combat, the reality is that no military solution is possible. We can't save the Afghanistan people from themselves. What is worse? A totalitarian state run by religious fanatics, or never ending war that takes the lives of many thousands each year and makes life impossible for everyone.

We have supported terrible tyrannical dictators over the decades because it suited our interests. Why is the Taliban any worse? Declare victory and let the locals sort it out. We can't lose something that is already lost.
Did you just jinx the Cubbies????
The Nats are certainly doing their share in helping them achieve that goal.
The NATS are going in the wrong direction, certainly, see 49A.
Martin, clever concept for a puzzle and nicely executed. Maybe a trifle hard for a Monday though.
Close enough for a Monday.

A post of mine got nixed on the old crossword forum because of an unfortunate typo: a letter omission in "peninsula."  It took a while to figure that one out.  I was impressed with the emus' command of Latin.

Healthcare mustn't be a commodity to be squeezed for profits (although that's what it is in the USA). Do Republicans really expect people to seek out the cheapest medical option? Do they do that themselves? If they have, say, heart problems, do they look for a low-priced medic, or do they try to find the best cardiologist possible? Most people who have health coverage also have a doctor they trust; are they really expected to check around for someone cheaper if they have a health problem? And how would they do that, exactly? I found it difficult just to find a dentist in a emergency, and paid a couple of thousand dollars for the repairs, but even if I had been able to call around and find out prices other dentists charged, I doubt that I'd have found anything cheaper--and even if I had, the procedure might well have been declared more complicated than expected, and the price would have gone up. The consumer simply can't control medical costs except by avoiding medical treatment, and that's what the theorists can't seem to understand.
I had an after-dinner drink tonight at the Mothers' Day meal, at a nice restaurant. The server asked, "Neat or on the rocks?"
My understanding of neat is unadulterated by anything, including ice. That said, I prefer my Jameson's on ice. It's taste improves when slightly diluted for my minor sipping.

Mac, how are things going? You're here a bit more so is it safe to assume that things are going well?

I used to think it was a sacrilege to add water to whiskey. But a rep at one of the distillers displays at Heathrow Airport disabused me of that opinion. She only added a splash of water and it really made a difference. Too bad that was at the END of my trip to Scotland!

Nice puzzle for a Monday but free of challenges. One quibble: Where I come from, "Neat" in a drink specification, used mostly by a guest in someone's home rather than as an order in a bar, means no water or mixer—in other words, straight. "Straight up," used mainly in a bar order, NO ICE.

Deb: As an old warhorse of an editor, I couldn't resist suggesting that if you had it to do over again, in your second paragraph you would have written "Anyway, after solving Dan Scheonholz's puzzle, I thought of all the times I played this game with my own children." Sorry . . .
I had an after-dinner drink tonight at the Mothers' Day meal, at a nice restaurant. The server asked, "Neat or on the rocks?"

I first had the opportunity to read the WSJ on a steady basis about 1958, when a fellow worker would leave it in the lunch room.

Being somewhat economically naive at the time I became convinced the country was on the verge of bankruptcy and hyper inflation. It all sounded so reasonable, and the cure was to return to the gold standard so the FED could not just keep in printing money like Germany did in the 1920s.

As the years rolled by, and wages increased, and my income did so also, these things never seemed to materialize. I read the neo classical economist, the Keynesians, and books on the market. Then Nixon allowed the value of gold to float, and yet no crash, no Armageddon. All the gloom and doom gravitated to the conservatives for simply political purposes, not for the benefit of the country as they would like you to think, but to reinforce their agenda, which is to shrink government. Even as our population grows, as demands on infrastructure grows, as income disparity rises, they continue to preach better times ahead by austerity. Despite historical evidence to the contrary.

Now their evasions, lies, misinformation is catching up, and they are paying the price. They will not give up easily, they will fight to the last to keep up their pretenses. They can not face reality, their little egos will not let them.

I truly admire Han Shan's courage in rejecting China's contemporary values. However, I disagree with the author's conclusion. Is the definition of materialism 'having a job and making a living'? I don't think so. Materialism means you value material things over all else (e.g. nature). Perhaps the author should check the dictionary about that. Everyone has to survive, somehow, don't they?

Not close enough, Martin but precisely on point.

BTW, the Cubs are playing .800 baseball which means they are on the way to winning 131 games. That's a lot of wins.

Aha! Very interesting. So Ned will pick him up and take him back to Winterfell where Catlyn would apparently already be waiting with toddler Robb already in tow, passing Jon off thenceforth as his own wild oats. My head is spinning.
Agreed. In season 1 episode 1 , Ned tells Jon that he will tell him of his mother one day. Perhaps by keeping Jon's parentage a secret he was protecting Jon from his friend King Robert Boratheon.
We didn't witness Jon Snow's birth but we may have overheard it.
Tower of Joy? Not without an epidural. We just witnessed the birth of John Snow.

"mash-up of Sturgis and Burning Man"

Hilarious visuals, that one. Oh, and Dothraki sickle-swords.

It's more like the viewership is post-peak. Having 10 months to speculate on the fate of Jon Snow made anything that happened to him a letdown. And the viewership then pats itself on the back about it and ignores the other great stuff that's happening. Like seeing how Varys does an interrogation, and learning who his "little birds" are. Like Cersei and Jaime playing their big move of taking over the Small Council only to see them fail. Like Arya being willing to drink from the well. Like Jon quitting the Night's Watch.

But everyone should keep patting themselves on the back about Jon being resurrected and what happened in the Tower of Joy, and ignore the other 90% of the show.

We already know who Varys's little birds are. We learned in Season one or two that Varys pays children to spy for him. And we saw him similarly offer Shae a chest of wealth if she would leave King's Landing. That's his MO. He buys what he wants from people. He does not torture or kill.
It all seems so predictable. Is GoT post-peak?
yes, please give Tyrion something more interesting to do.  Nothing this season has been as good as, "That's what I do.  I drink, and I know things."

Martin calls it an epic of 'fire and snow' for a reason!  I think the battle lines are fairly well drawn at this point with D and J combining forces with 3 dragons against the Winter hoards.  Many of the non-Stark characters are unlikely to be around for the big battle and they are mostly 'B plot' distractions in this season.

Interesting how things are shaking out.  The plot seems to be converging around the characters that we met in the beginning at Winterfell.  Jon has come back from the dead and left the Night's Watch, making him something of a free agent.  The Three-eyed Raven says he's been waiting specifically for Bran and is equipping him with knowledge of past events.  Arya has finally completed her training at the House of Black and White. Sansa has freed herself from Ramsay and has Brienne to help her.  Now, Rickon suddenly reappears.  Feels like they're all moving towards something.  Please get Tyrion out of Meereen, though.  His wit is wasted there.
Mace Tyrell looks like the mayor of Munchkinland.

Kevan is killed in the books at the behest of a character that is not in the TV show. There's actually no room for him because it would splinter the story even further. Not sure how they're going to wrap up this series in two abbreviated seasons as it is.

Pretty sure Arya has always been free to come and go; staying to learn to become one of the "Faceless Men" is her decision. Jaqen H'ghar (the dude who's been training her, and who gave her the Braavosi coin way back a couple of seasons ago) would certainly not oblige her to stay if he felt her commitment was not there.

Spoilers: Great to see Varys at work again, he's been Costello to Tyrion's Abbott for too long. Not sure if he made the traitor woman "happy" or killed her via the "leader-clad friend" he mentioned, but he did get the information he wanted - yep, he's back!  The reanimated Jon Snow has not gotten any extra energy from this trip into the afterlife - still the same drooping around. Handing over the Lord Commander role seemed very perfunctory - his watch is certainly over!  Where's he going - Winterfell to fight with Ramsay? Knight's Landing to fight with Cersei/Jaime/Sparrows? People who have had near death experiences are often psychic on their return - will Jon now have visions to rival Bran's?  It is strange to have so many of Ned Stark's children in desperate peril - Jon came back from the dead but is still a marked man, Arya got her sight back but still has no freedom, Sansa is on the run and has one friend (Brienne) to protect her, Rickon is now entrapped by Ramsay - and may soon be missing important parts of himself, if Ramsay goes the Reek route. The Tyrion game segment fell really flat - but the Small Council meeting was very funny. Great to see Diana Rigg back as the sharp-tongued relative of Margery, reminding Cersei that she is not the queen, and that the Lannister family tree is very twisted, indeed. Uncle Kevan is dead in the books, murdered by children, but in the show, he's alive and kicking Cersei in the shins. We missed the dragons! And where is Littlefinger??

This episode felt hurried to me. I couldn't really settle into any of the plotlines before we moved on to the next one. I don't know why it has to be this way. By far the most interesting story was Arya's story. Now that she has her eyesight back, I wonder what's in store of her.

Jon Snow was a huge letdown this week. He woke up and he seems to be having some sort of post-death crisis. It was not very compelling. I hope they can make that plot more interesting in the coming weeks.

Sam and Gilli had a sweet moment, of course marred by puke, but I was so happy to see them. I feel like Jon Snow's storyline needs the comic relief that Sam provides.

Also, pretty awkward in Mereen. I had high hopes for Tyron in Mereen, but it just does not seem to make that plotline any better. I don't care enough about the Sons for the Harpy or that city.

Not quite sure what's the significance of Bran's vision. I hope we learn soon.

But is it really Rickon? Isn't he with Bran? I can't remember now. And if we have another few weeks of torture courtesy of Ramsey, I don't think I'd be able to take it.

Good call on Bran maybe altering the history of Westerose. Maybe at the expense of his own life. You heard the three eyed raven--he's not supposed to alter the past. Maybe he will. Do you think he'll bring Ned back?

Ryan is not a con man, he is a conned man. He is a deluded ideologue who believes his own views and facts given to him by the party.

Just as Himmler and Eichmann believed Der Fuhrers rhetoric, so Ryan believes the rhetoric of the GOP ideologues. Just listen to them, they say the same thing time after time, despite evidence they are one step short of psychotic. In a more rational culture, we would put them in a place where they could not hurt themselves.

There is no Condorcet paradox in this case because (a) the primaries took place in different states with different constituencies - whereas the Condorcet paradox took place in a single assembly with the same set of voters and (b) even if there had been a single national primary the other candidates were so weak that Trump would have won in a pair-wise vote against any single contender. Rational choice theory does have some insights to offer but it is repeatedly misused by being applied to inappropriate cases.
I didn't perceive mocking at all.

I have to say; when an American decides to move back to the land to raise free-range chickens or create artisanal cheeses in an effort to escape the rat race they are practically deified by this paper.  This Miao Chinese is gently mocked.
My understanding of neat is unadulterated by anything, including ice. That said, I prefer my Jameson's on ice. It's taste improves when slightly diluted for my minor sipping.
When we lose our connection with nature we lose our sense of proportion. Han Shan is blessed that he was born into a culture that still valued its connection to the natural world.

The national debt as a percentage of gross domestic product only became a problem when Ronald Reagan cut taxes for the rich. When the top tax rate never got below 70% the national debt as a percentage of gross domestic product declined. It declined under Republican and Democratic presidents. It declined during the wars in Korea and Vietnam.
Seems to me that's true of both parties, just (perhaps) less obvious this year among the Democrats.

[The King said] 'Just look along the road, and tell me if you can see either of them.'

'I see nobody on the road,' said Alice.

'I only wish I had such eyes,' the King remarked in a fretful tone. 'To be able to see Nobody! And at the distance too! Why, it's as much as I can do to see real people, by this light!'
